title: Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution
abstract:
Knowledge distillation (KD) is a promising yet challenging model compression
technique that transfers rich learning representations from a well-performing
but cumbersome teacher model to a compact student model. Previous methods for
image super-resolution (SR) mostly compare the feature maps directly or after
standardizing the dimensions with basic algebraic operations (e.g. average,
dot-product). However, the intrinsic semantic differences among feature maps
are overlooked, which are caused by the disparate expressive capacity between
the networks. This work presents MiPKD, a multi-granularity mixture of prior KD
framework, to facilitate efficient SR model through the feature mixture in a
unified latent space and stochastic network block mixture. Extensive
experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed MiPKD method.

# Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution

Simiao Li1   Yun Zhang1,2âˆ—\*   Wei Li1   Hanting Chen1

Wenjia Wang2   Bingyi Jing3   Shaohui Lin4   Jie Hu1

1Huawei Noahâ€™s Ark Lab

2Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (GZ)

3Southern University of Science and Technology

4East China Normal University

{wei.lee, lisimiao}@huawei.comyzhangjy@connect.ust.hk
Both authors contributed equally to this researchCorresponding author: hujie23@huawei.com

###### Abstract

Knowledge distillation (KD) is a promising yet challenging model compression technique that transfers rich learning representations from a well-performing but cumbersome teacher model to a compact student model.
Previous methods for image super-resolution (SR) mostly compare the feature maps directly or after standardizing the dimensions with basic algebraic operations (e.g. average, dot-product).
However, the intrinsic semantic differences among feature maps are overlooked, which are caused by the disparate expressive capacity between the networks.
This work presents MiPKD, a multi-granularity mixture of prior KD framework, to facilitate efficient SR model
through the feature mixture in a unified latent space and stochastic network block mixture.
Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed MiPKD method.

###### Keywords:

Image Super-Resolution Knowledge Distillation Model Compression

## 1 Introduction

Super-resolution (SR) is a fundamental yet challenging task in the field of computer vision (CV), to restore high-resolution (HR) images from their low-resolution (LR) counterparts \[ [7](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib7 ""), [20](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib20 ""), [3](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib3 "")\]. In the past decade, convolutional neural network (CNN) \[ [6](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib6 ""), [16](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib16 ""), [21](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib21 ""), [49](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib49 ""), [5](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib5 "")\] and Transformer \[ [3](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib3 ""), [20](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib20 ""), [41](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib41 ""), [44](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib44 ""), [46](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib46 "")\] have demonstrated exceptional success for SR.
However, it is impractical to directly deploy these models on resource-limited devices due to their heavy computation overload \[ [51](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib51 "")\].
Consequently, there has been a growing interest in model compression for SR models to facilitate their real-world applications.

![Refer to caption](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573/assets/x1.png)Figure 1: The PSNR of student models on Urban100 testset under different compression settings. In the depth compression (a), there are barely KD methods outperforming vanilla logits-KD. For width compression (b), CSD performs well but only satisfies this setting. For compounded compression, almost all KD underperforms training without KD.

Knowledge distillation, emerging as an effective model compression method, can significantly reduce the computation overload, facilitating the student by transferring dark knowledge from the well-performed but cumbersome teacher model to the compact one \[ [48](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib48 ""), [23](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib23 ""), [15](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib15 ""), [18](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib18 "")\]. Compared with other model compression techniques, such as quantization \[ [19](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib19 ""), [13](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib13 ""), [24](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib24 "")\], pruning \[ [38](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib38 ""), [40](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib40 "")\], compact block design \[ [1](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib1 ""), [33](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib33 ""), [27](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib27 ""), [37](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib37 "")\], and neural architecture search (NAS) \[ [53](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib53 ""), [36](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib36 ""), [31](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib31 "")\], KD is a widely recognized method that can be combined with aforementioned techniques to further improve the compactness of student model.
KD for SR has also attracted wide attention recently and gained remarkable progress \[ [19](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib19 ""), [18](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib18 ""), [48](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib48 ""), [11](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib11 ""), [40](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib40 ""), [52](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib52 "")\]. These methods can be roughly categorized into response-based KD and feature-based KD, the former utilizes the output of the teacher model to supervise the training process of the student model, while the latter tries to align the
hidden representations between the teacher model and the student model \[ [9](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib9 ""), [40](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib40 ""), [11](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib11 "")\].

Though previous KD methods show promising results in SR, several issues hinder the wide applications of them. First, existing KD techniques for SR are tailored to specific teacher-student architectures. They support either network depth ( [Fig.1](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S1.F1 "In 1 Introduction â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") (a)) or network width ( [Fig.1](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S1.F1 "In 1 Introduction â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") (b)) compression \[ [11](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib11 "")\], and deteriorates the student dramatically when adopting them into another setting. For instance, FAKD \[ [11](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib11 "")\] boosts the student model in depth compression but deteriorates the student when applied to a width compression circumstance. CSD \[ [40](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib40 "")\] improves the student model significantly (Fig. [1](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S1.F1 "Figure 1 â€£ 1 Introduction â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") (b)) but is not compatible with depth compression in Fig. [1](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S1.F1 "Figure 1 â€£ 1 Introduction â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") (a).
Itâ€™s necessary to propose a more flexible KD framework which is closer to real-world application.
While few methods have discussed the compounded compression on both depth and width dimension, which is a much more general but challenging scenario.
To be specific, FAKD and those feature-based KD methods introduced from high-level CV, e.g. RKD \[ [28](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib28 "")\], AT \[ [43](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib43 "")\], and FitNet \[ [32](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib32 "")\] hardly benefit the student model.
[Fig.1](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S1.F1 "In 1 Introduction â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") (a) shows that the previous depth and channel distillation methods can just obtain a marginal performance gain or even deteriorate the student in most cases.
To alleivate these issues, in this paper, we present a novel knowledge distillation framework for SR models, the multi-granularity mixture of prior knowledge distillation (MiPKD), that is universally applicable to a wide array of teacher-student architectures at feature and block levels.
Specifically, the feature prior mixer first dynamically combines priors from the teacher and the student and then is
supervised by the teacherâ€™s feature map. The block prior mixer adopts a coarser-grained prior mixture at the network block level that dynamically switches the normal forward propagation path to the teacher or the student. The final output of this newly ensembled sub-network is further supervised by the teacherâ€™s response.

In summary, the main contributions of this paper are as follows:

- âˆ™âˆ™\\bullet


We present MiPKD, a KD framework for efficient SR, transferring the teacher modelâ€™s prior knowledge from both network width and depth levels. Itâ€™s more flexible and applicable to a wide array of teacher-student architectures.

- âˆ™âˆ™\\bullet


We propose the feature and block prior mixers to reduce the capacity disparity between teacher and student models for better alignment. The former combines the feature maps in a unified latent space, while the latter assembles dynamic combination of network blocks from teacher and student models.

- âˆ™âˆ™\\bullet


Extensive experiments on various benchmarks show that the proposed MiPKD framework significantly outperforms the previous arts.


## 2 Related Work

Deep SISR Models. Deep neural networks (DNNs) based image super-resolution have shown impressive success. Dong et al.\[ [6](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib6 "")\] firstly introduced CNN with only three Conv layers for image SR. Residual learning was introduced in VDSR \[ [16](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib16 "")\], reaching 20 Conv layers. Lim et al. proposed EDSR \[ [21](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib21 "")\] with simplified residual block \[ [10](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib10 "")\]. Zhang et al. proposed an even deeper network RCAN \[ [49](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib49 "")\].
Later, Mei et al. proposed CSNLN \[ [50](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib50 "")\] by combining feature correlations, and external statistics. Most of them have achieved state-of-the-art results with deeper and wider networks. Recently, Transformer has gained a surge of interest for image restoration. Chen et al. proposed the first pre-trained image processing transformer IPT \[ [3](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib3 "")\].
SwinIR \[ [20](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib20 "")\] first applies the residual Swin Transformer block to the image restoration for deep feature extraction.
Restormer \[ [44](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib44 "")\] proposed a multi-scale hierarchical design that incorporates efficient Transformer blocks by modifying self-attention and MLP.
Similarly, Uformer \[ [41](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib41 "")\] proposed a LeWin Transformer block for image restoration. While CNNs and Transformers have demonstrated impressive performance in SISR, they suffer from heavy memory cost and computational overhead.

Efficient SISR.
To improve the model efficiency, various approaches have been proposed to reduce modelâ€™s redundancy, such as neural architecture search (NAS) \[ [4](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib4 ""), [34](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib34 "")\], compact block design \[ [1](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib1 ""), [33](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib33 ""), [27](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib27 ""), [37](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib37 ""), [41](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib41 ""), [44](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib44 "")\], pruning \[ [38](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib38 ""), [40](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib40 "")\], and low-bit quantization \[ [24](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib24 ""), [19](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib19 ""), [13](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib13 "")\]. The strength of NAS manifests in searching the optimal architecture but is time-consuming and computationally expensive due to the massive search space.
Afterwards, compact SR model designs have attracted rising attention and achieved remarkable progress \[ [47](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib47 ""), [15](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib15 ""), [1](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib1 ""), [8](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib8 "")\].
Zhang et al. proposed ELAN \[ [47](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib47 "")\] that designs a group-wise multi-scale self-attention (GMSA) module to exploit the long-range image dependency, achieving even better results against the transformer-based SR models but with significantly less complexity.
Pruning \[ [38](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib38 ""), [40](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib40 "")\] and quantization \[ [24](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib24 ""), [19](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib19 ""), [13](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib13 "")\] are other two types of methods to remove model redundancy by sparsity and low-bit quantization mappings. Although those lightweight networks have achieved great progress, they still need considerable extra computation resources.

Knowledge Distillation for SISR.
Knowledge distillation is widely recognized as an effective model compression method that can significantly reduce the computation overload and improve studentâ€™s capability by transferring dark knowledge from the large teacher model to the lightweight student model \[ [9](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib9 ""), [42](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib42 ""), [12](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib12 "")\].
Recently, several attempts have also been made for image super-resolution knowledge distillation.
Lee _et al_. \[ [18](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib18 "")\] first pre-trained the encoder and decoder using the pairs of the same HR images, and the privileged information is extracted from the decoder to obtain the statistical output location and scale maps as the knowledge.
He _et al._ proposed FAKD \[ [11](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib11 "")\] to distill the second-order statistical information from the affinity matrix of feature maps.
Wang _et al._ proposed CSD that incorporates self-distillation and contrastive learning \[ [40](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib40 "")\] by introducing extra simply upsampled LR images as negative samples.
However, none of the existing SRKD methods have discussed how to customize a proper teacher for a student with limited capacity or whether a stronger teacher consistently benefits the capacity-limited student.
Furthermore, existing SRKD techniques for SR are tailored to specific teacher-student architectures, focusing on either network depth \[ [40](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib40 "")\] or channel compression \[ [11](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib11 "")\], which is infeasible for practical compounded compression applications.

The feature prior mixer dynamically combines priors from the teacher and student, and the block prior mixer adopts a coarser-grained prior mixture at the network block level.

### 3.2 Mixture of Prior Knowledge Distillation

According to earlier research and analysis, there is a negative correlation between student performance and the teacherâ€™s modelâ€™s capacity as the capacity gap widens between students and teachers \[ [26](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib26 "")\]. Since the student models struggle to grasp the capacity to extract semantic information from the bigger model. In the process of feature distillation, it is crucial to illustrate the effective retrieval and transfer of the teacherâ€™s prior knowledge to the student network.
Our proposed feature distillation method,
surpasses FAKD, CSD and other deep or channel kd methods as Fig. [1](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S1.F1 "Figure 1 â€£ 1 Introduction â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") shown. This is accomplished by incorporating the teacherâ€™s knowledge with the studentâ€™s network at feature and block levels, within a stochastic dynamic framework. This approach reduces the capacity disparity between the teacher and student, thereby enhancing the performance of the student model.

Block Prior Mixer.

Existing feature-based distillation methods on SR tasks mostly align the feature representations in the original space with Mean Absolute Error (MAE) or Mean Square Error (MSE).
Previous studies \[ [29](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib29 "")\] shows that distinct controllability properties and semantics may exist among the network of the similar architecture with various weights.
Student and teacher models with various dimensional space typically exist seperate distribution of semantic information \[ [22](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib22 "")\].
Therefore, solely aligning features at the present distillation node with the same magnitudes of distance can leads the student model to learn entirely different information.
To tackle this issue, we propose to align the networksâ€™ ability of processing and representing information by assembling a dynamic combination of blocks and transmitting the fusion information from the Feature Prior Mixer to the enhanced network.

â„¬O(k)subscriptâ„¬subscriptğ‘‚ğ‘˜\\mathcal{B}\_{{O}\_{(k)}} represents the mixed block at the current position based on RksubscriptRğ‘˜\\mathrm{R}\_{k} and DksubscriptDğ‘˜\\mathrm{D}\_{k} as formula [6](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S3.E6 "Equation 6 â€£ 3.2 Mixture of Prior Knowledge Distillation â€£ 3 Methodology â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") shown.

|  | â„¬O(k)=Dkâ€‹(Rkâ€‹â„¬S(k)+(1âˆ’Rk)â€‹â„¬T(k)).subscriptâ„¬subscriptğ‘‚ğ‘˜subscriptDğ‘˜subscriptRğ‘˜subscriptâ„¬subscriptğ‘†ğ‘˜1subscriptRğ‘˜subscriptâ„¬subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘˜\\mathcal{B}\_{{O}\_{(k)}}=\\mathrm{D}\_{k}(\\mathrm{R}\_{k}\\mathcal{B}\_{{S}\_{(k)}}+(1-\\mathrm{R}\_{k})\\mathcal{B}\_{{T}\_{(k)}}). |  | (6) |

In general,

Meanwhile, RksubscriptRğ‘˜\\mathrm{R}\_{k} and DksubscriptDğ‘˜\\mathrm{D}\_{k} determine the transmission direction of ğ…kEsubscriptsuperscriptğ…ğ¸ğ‘˜{\\mathbf{F}}^{E}\_{k} for each iteration, the studentsâ€™ network for random block information is also exchanged and transmitted by the teacherâ€™s as Fig. [2](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S3.F2 "Figure 2 â€£ 3 Methodology â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") shown.

We compare MiPKD with the baselines: train from scratch, Logits-KD \[ [12](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib12 "")\], RKD \[ [28](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib28 "")\], AT \[ [43](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib43 "")\], FitNet \[ [32](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib32 "")\], FAKD \[ [11](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib11 "")\], and CSD \[ [40](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib40 "")\]. Since the CSD is a self-distillation method in the channel-spliting manner, itâ€™s not applicable to the RCAN experiments of network depth distillation.
The results for Ã—4 EDSR trained with CSD are obtained by testing the provided checkpoint, and the Ã—2 and Ã—3 ones are reproduced by us since the checkpoints are unavailable.
To evaluate quality of SR modelâ€™s output, we calculate the peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) and the structural similarity index (SSIM) on the Y channel of the YCbCr color space. We use 800 images from DIV2K \[ [35](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib35 "")\] for training and evaluate SR models on four benchmark datasets: Set5 \[ [2](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib2 "")\], Set14 \[ [45](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib45 "")\], BSD100 \[ [25](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib25 "")\], and Urban100 \[ [14](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib14 "")\].

Training Details. All models are trained using Adam \[ [17](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib17 "")\] optimizer with Î²1=0.9subscriptğ›½10.9\\beta\_{1}=0.9, Î²2=0.99subscriptğ›½20.99\\beta\_{2}=0.99 and Ïµ=10âˆ’8italic-Ïµsuperscript108\\epsilon=10^{-8}, with a batch size of 16 and a total of 2.5Ã—1052.5superscript1052.5\\times 10^{5} updates. The initial learning rate is set to 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4} and is decayed by a factor of 10 at every 105superscript10510^{5} iteration. We set the loss weights Î»1subscriptğœ†1\\lambda\_{1} and Î»2subscriptğœ†2\\lambda\_{2} to 10 and 1, respectively. The proposed MiPKD is implemented by the BasicSR \[ [39](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib39 "")\] and PyTorch \[ [30](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib30 "")\] framework and train them using 4 NVIDIA V100 GPUs. The LR images used for training and evaluation were obtained by down-sampling the HR images with the bicubic degradation method. During training, the input images are randomly cropped into 48Ã—48484848\\times 48 patches and augmented with random horizontal/vertical flips and rotations.

Comparison with Baseline Methods.
Quantitative results for training EDSR \[ [21](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib21 "")\], RCAN \[ [49](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib49 "")\], and SwinIR \[ [20](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib20 "")\] of three SR scales
are presented in [Tab.2](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S4.T2 "In 4.1 Experiment Setups â€£ 4 Experimental Results â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution"), [Tab.3](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S4.T3 "In 4.1 Experiment Setups â€£ 4 Experimental Results â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") and [Tab.4](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S4.T4 "In 4.2 Results and Comparison â€£ 4 Experimental Results â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution"), from which we can draw the following conclusions:

(1) Existing KD methods for SR have limited effects, some may even deteriorate the student model. The KD methods originally designed for high-level CV tasks (RKD, AT, FitNet), though applicable, hardly improve the SR models over training from scratch. For instance, AT and FitNet underperform the vanilla student models trained without KD among all settings.

(2) The presented MiPKD outperforms existing KD methods baseline in width and depth compression, respectively.
For example, MiPKD outperforms the vanilla student in the most challenging dataset Urban100 in EDSRÃ—\\times2, Ã—\\times3, and Ã—\\times4 settings by
0.56 dB, 0.42 dB, 0.24 dB
in terms of PSNR, respectively as [Tab.2](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S4.T2 "In 4.1 Experiment Setups â€£ 4 Experimental Results â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") shown. For depth distillation, compared with trainning from scratch,
0.2 dB, 0.17 dB, 0.19 dB
in terms of PSNR are improved, respectively, on Urban100 dataset in RCAN Ã—\\times2, Ã—\\times3, and Ã—\\times4 settings as [Tab.3](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S4.T3 "In 4.1 Experiment Setups â€£ 4 Experimental Results â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") shown.

(3) The MiPKD is applicable to Transformer network and able to boost the modelâ€™s performance. Conventional feature-based KD methods are not directly applicable to the Transformer-type networks, so we compare MiPKD with training from scratch and the response-based KD \[ [12](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib12 "")\] in the experiments. The results in  [Tab.4](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S4.T4 "In 4.2 Results and Comparison â€£ 4 Experimental Results â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") indicate that the MiPKD could improve the transformer SR model by a large margin, further emphasizing its superior performance.

Evaluate MiPKD on high compression rate setting. [Tab.5](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S4.T5 "In 4.2 Results and Comparison â€£ 4 Experimental Results â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") shows the results of training Ã—4 scale EDSR model compressed in both network width and depth dimensions. The number of parameters are compressed for about 28 times from teacher model.
Directly distilling the student model by the teacher model yields negative effects on its performance. Two-stage KD with an intermediate teaching-assistant (TA) model \[ [26](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#bib.bib26 "")\] are necessary in such case.
To make use of the CSD method, we compared different TA options, (1) Teacher->Student1->Student2: the whole pipeline is in a width-then-depth compression order. We adopt CSD to train the TA and FAKD for student. model (2) Depth-then-width: we first perform depth compression and then width compression. We adopt FAKD+CSD and MiPKD+MiPKD for the two-stage distillations. Using MiPKD to train both TA and student model yields the best results.

Visual Comparison. [Fig.3](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S4.F3 "In 4.2 Results and Comparison â€£ 4 Experimental Results â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") compares the output of Ã—4 RCAN models differently trained for four images from the Urban100 dataset. For instance, for iâ€‹mâ€‹gâ€‹\_â€‹047ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘”\_047img\\\_047, MiPKD can reconstruct much better fine details than all baseline work. FAKD are prone to artifacts in the left-bottom of the building and the vanilla student, Logits-KD, FAKD, and FitNet are over-blurred. In contrast, MiPKD alleviates the blurring artifacts and reconstructs much more structural details. Similar observations can be found in other cases, e.g. the characters and anisotropic textures in iâ€‹mâ€‹gâ€‹\_â€‹073ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘”\_073img\\\_073. These visual comparisons are consistent with the quantitative results, demonstrating the superiority of MiPKD. More visual comparisons can be found in the supplementary materials.

## 5 Ablation Study

To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed MiPKD scheme, we conduct detailed ablation studies on Ã—multiple scale RCAN and EDSR networks.

Ablation on the feature and block prior mixers for MipKD.
There are two fine-grained prior mixer modules in MiPKD, namely, the feature and block prior mixers. Their individual effects are ablated in [Tab.6](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S5.T6 "In 5 Ablation Study â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution"). The result shows that employing the feature prior mixers leads to significant performance improvement and the block prior mixer based on it could further boost the student model.

Ablation on the MiPKD feature prior mixer module.
In the feature prior mixer module of MiPKD, the teacher and student modelsâ€™ feature maps are mapped to the latent space through corresponding encoders, thereby randomly mixed and stitched.
We present an analysis of the impact of the encoders in [Tab.7](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S5.T7 "In 5 Ablation Study â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") by comparing MiPKD with 1) removing the encoders, aligning and utilizing the teacherâ€™s feature map directly and 2) sharing a encoder among the teacher and student model.
Removing the encoders would substantially deteriorate the student modelâ€™s performance. Due to the different distribution of teacher and student modelsâ€™ feature maps, a shared encoder cannot effectively map them to the same latent space, leading to noisy mixtures.
Assigning the teacher and student models separate encoders yields the best results, indicating that mixing feature priors in the same latent space is necessary.

[Tab.8](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S5.T8 "In 5 Ablation Study â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") compares the encoders and decoder of different architecture. The result shows that convolutional neural network type exhibits better performance and is more suitable in SR task.

Besides, the strategies of the mask generation are compared in [Tab.9](https://ar5iv.org/html/2404.02573#S5.T9 "In 5 Ablation Study â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution"). Compared with 1) masking according to the Cosine or CKA similarity between teacher and student modelsâ€™ feature maps or 2) generating the complementary pairs of feature map by fixed grid pattern, the random 3D-mask exhibits the best performance and least calculation consumption. A more flexible, generalisable strategy is applied in the prior mixer module.

## 6 Conclusion

In this paper, we present MiPKD, a simple yet significant KD framework for SR with feature and block mixers.
By incorporating the prior knowledge from teacher model to the student, the capacity disparity between them are reduced, and the feature alignment is achieved effectively.
We compare the proposed MiPKD with various kinds of distillation methods and demonstrate the superiority of our solutions.
For instance, it improves the EDSR network of three SR scale on Urban100 testing set in the range of 0.24 dBâˆ¼similar-to\\sim0.56 dB in terms of PSNR.
The presented MiPKD outperforms existing KD methods baseline in width, depth compression and compounded compression in SR tasks, which is flexible to a wide array of teacher-student kd architectures.

1 Introduction.content:
Super-resolution (SR) is a fundamental yet challenging task in the field of computer vision (CV), to restore high-resolution (HR) images from their low-resolution (LR) counterparts \[ [7], [20], [3]\]. In the past decade, convolutional neural network (CNN) \[ [6], [16], [21], [49], [5]\] and Transformer \[ [3], [20], [41], [44], [46]\] have demonstrated exceptional success for SR.
However, it is impractical to directly deploy these models on resource-limited devices due to their heavy computation overload \[ [51]\].
Consequently, there has been a growing interest in model compression for SR models to facilitate their real-world applications.

![Refer to caption]Figure 1: The PSNR of student models on Urban100 testset under different compression settings. In the depth compression (a), there are barely KD methods outperforming vanilla logits-KD. For width compression (b), CSD performs well but only satisfies this setting. For compounded compression, almost all KD underperforms training without KD.

Knowledge distillation, emerging as an effective model compression method, can significantly reduce the computation overload, facilitating the student by transferring dark knowledge from the well-performed but cumbersome teacher model to the compact one \[ [48], [23], [15], [18]\]. Compared with other model compression techniques, such as quantization \[ [19], [13], [24]\], pruning \[ [38], [40]\], compact block design \[ [1], [33], [27], [37]\], and neural architecture search (NAS) \[ [53], [36], [31]\], KD is a widely recognized method that can be combined with aforementioned techniques to further improve the compactness of student model.
KD for SR has also attracted wide attention recently and gained remarkable progress \[ [19], [18], [48], [11], [40], [52]\]. These methods can be roughly categorized into response-based KD and feature-based KD, the former utilizes the output of the teacher model to supervise the training process of the student model, while the latter tries to align the
hidden representations between the teacher model and the student model \[ [9], [40], [11]\].

Though previous KD methods show promising results in SR, several issues hinder the wide applications of them. First, existing KD techniques for SR are tailored to specific teacher-student architectures. They support either network depth ( [Fig.1]In 1 Introduction â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") (a)) or network width ( [Fig.1]In 1 Introduction â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") (b)) compression \[ [11]\], and deteriorates the student dramatically when adopting them into another setting. For instance, FAKD \[ [11]\] boosts the student model in depth compression but deteriorates the student when applied to a width compression circumstance. CSD \[ [40]\] improves the student model significantly (Fig. [1]Figure 1 â€£ 1 Introduction â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") (b)) but is not compatible with depth compression in Fig. [1]Figure 1 â€£ 1 Introduction â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") (a).
Itâ€™s necessary to propose a more flexible KD framework which is closer to real-world application.
While few methods have discussed the compounded compression on both depth and width dimension, which is a much more general but challenging scenario.
To be specific, FAKD and those feature-based KD methods introduced from high-level CV, e.g. RKD \[ [28]\], AT \[ [43]\], and FitNet \[ [32]\] hardly benefit the student model.
[Fig.1]In 1 Introduction â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") (a) shows that the previous depth and channel distillation methods can just obtain a marginal performance gain or even deteriorate the student in most cases.
To alleivate these issues, in this paper, we present a novel knowledge distillation framework for SR models, the multi-granularity mixture of prior knowledge distillation (MiPKD), that is universally applicable to a wide array of teacher-student architectures at feature and block levels.
Specifically, the feature prior mixer first dynamically combines priors from the teacher and the student and then is
supervised by the teacherâ€™s feature map. The block prior mixer adopts a coarser-grained prior mixture at the network block level that dynamically switches the normal forward propagation path to the teacher or the student. The final output of this newly ensembled sub-network is further supervised by the teacherâ€™s response.

In summary, the main contributions of this paper are as follows:

- âˆ™âˆ™\\bullet


We present MiPKD, a KD framework for efficient SR, transferring the teacher modelâ€™s prior knowledge from both network width and depth levels. Itâ€™s more flexible and applicable to a wide array of teacher-student architectures.

- âˆ™âˆ™\\bullet


We propose the feature and block prior mixers to reduce the capacity disparity between teacher and student models for better alignment. The former combines the feature maps in a unified latent space, while the latter assembles dynamic combination of network blocks from teacher and student models.

- âˆ™âˆ™\\bullet


Extensive experiments on various benchmarks show that the proposed MiPKD framework significantly outperforms the previous arts.

2 Related Work.content:
Deep SISR Models. Deep neural networks (DNNs) based image super-resolution have shown impressive success. Dong et al.\[ [6]\] firstly introduced CNN with only three Conv layers for image SR. Residual learning was introduced in VDSR \[ [16]\], reaching 20 Conv layers. Lim et al. proposed EDSR \[ [21]\] with simplified residual block \[ [10]\]. Zhang et al. proposed an even deeper network RCAN \[ [49]\].
Later, Mei et al. proposed CSNLN \[ [50]\] by combining feature correlations, and external statistics. Most of them have achieved state-of-the-art results with deeper and wider networks. Recently, Transformer has gained a surge of interest for image restoration. Chen et al. proposed the first pre-trained image processing transformer IPT \[ [3]\].
SwinIR \[ [20]\] first applies the residual Swin Transformer block to the image restoration for deep feature extraction.
Restormer \[ [44]\] proposed a multi-scale hierarchical design that incorporates efficient Transformer blocks by modifying self-attention and MLP.
Similarly, Uformer \[ [41]\] proposed a LeWin Transformer block for image restoration. While CNNs and Transformers have demonstrated impressive performance in SISR, they suffer from heavy memory cost and computational overhead.

Efficient SISR.
To improve the model efficiency, various approaches have been proposed to reduce modelâ€™s redundancy, such as neural architecture search (NAS) \[ [4], [34]\], compact block design \[ [1], [33], [27], [37], [41], [44]\], pruning \[ [38], [40]\], and low-bit quantization \[ [24], [19], [13]\]. The strength of NAS manifests in searching the optimal architecture but is time-consuming and computationally expensive due to the massive search space.
Afterwards, compact SR model designs have attracted rising attention and achieved remarkable progress \[ [47], [15], [1], [8]\].
Zhang et al. proposed ELAN \[ [47]\] that designs a group-wise multi-scale self-attention (GMSA) module to exploit the long-range image dependency, achieving even better results against the transformer-based SR models but with significantly less complexity.
Pruning \[ [38], [40]\] and quantization \[ [24], [19], [13]\] are other two types of methods to remove model redundancy by sparsity and low-bit quantization mappings. Although those lightweight networks have achieved great progress, they still need considerable extra computation resources.

Knowledge Distillation for SISR.
Knowledge distillation is widely recognized as an effective model compression method that can significantly reduce the computation overload and improve studentâ€™s capability by transferring dark knowledge from the large teacher model to the lightweight student model \[ [9], [42], [12]\].
Recently, several attempts have also been made for image super-resolution knowledge distillation.
Lee _et al_. \[ [18]\] first pre-trained the encoder and decoder using the pairs of the same HR images, and the privileged information is extracted from the decoder to obtain the statistical output location and scale maps as the knowledge.
He _et al._ proposed FAKD \[ [11]\] to distill the second-order statistical information from the affinity matrix of feature maps.
Wang _et al._ proposed CSD that incorporates self-distillation and contrastive learning \[ [40]\] by introducing extra simply upsampled LR images as negative samples.
However, none of the existing SRKD methods have discussed how to customize a proper teacher for a student with limited capacity or whether a stronger teacher consistently benefits the capacity-limited student.
Furthermore, existing SRKD techniques for SR are tailored to specific teacher-student architectures, focusing on either network depth \[ [40]\] or channel compression \[ [11]\], which is infeasible for practical compounded compression applications.

citations.text: Zhang et al. proposed an even deeper network RCAN \[ [49]
Chen et al. proposed the first pre-trained image processing transformer IPT \[ [3]

### 3.2 Mixture of Prior Knowledge Distillation

According to earlier research and analysis, there is a negative correlation between student performance and the teacherâ€™s modelâ€™s capacity as the capacity gap widens between students and teachers \[ [26]\]. Since the student models struggle to grasp the capacity to extract semantic information from the bigger model. In the process of feature distillation, it is crucial to illustrate the effective retrieval and transfer of the teacherâ€™s prior knowledge to the student network.
Our proposed feature distillation method,
surpasses FAKD, CSD and other deep or channel kd methods as Fig. [1]Figure 1 â€£ 1 Introduction â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") shown. This is accomplished by incorporating the teacherâ€™s knowledge with the studentâ€™s network at feature and block levels, within a stochastic dynamic framework. This approach reduces the capacity disparity between the teacher and student, thereby enhancing the performance of the student model.

Block Prior Mixer.

Existing feature-based distillation methods on SR tasks mostly align the feature representations in the original space with Mean Absolute Error (MAE) or Mean Square Error (MSE).
Previous studies \[ [29]\] shows that distinct controllability properties and semantics may exist among the network of the similar architecture with various weights.
Student and teacher models with various dimensional space typically exist seperate distribution of semantic information \[ [22]\].
Therefore, solely aligning features at the present distillation node with the same magnitudes of distance can leads the student model to learn entirely different information.
To tackle this issue, we propose to align the networksâ€™ ability of processing and representing information by assembling a dynamic combination of blocks and transmitting the fusion information from the Feature Prior Mixer to the enhanced network.

In general,
for each feature distillation position kğ‘˜k, based on the pair of ğ…kTsubscriptsuperscriptğ…ğ‘‡ğ‘˜\\mathbf{F}^{T}\_{k} and ğ…kSsubscriptsuperscriptğ…ğ‘†ğ‘˜\\mathbf{F}^{S}\_{k} as the input of Feature Prior Mixer, the random masked feature map of student is populated and fused with the teacherâ€™s as ğ…kEsubscriptsuperscriptğ…ğ¸ğ‘˜{\\mathbf{F}}^{E}\_{k}, and the Lkfâ€‹eâ€‹aâ€‹tEsubscriptsuperscriptğ¿ğ‘“ğ‘’ğ‘subscriptğ‘¡ğ¸ğ‘˜{L}^{feat\_{E}}\_{k} is computed to align with the initial teacher feature map in the same distribution space.
Meanwhile, RksubscriptRğ‘˜\\mathrm{R}\_{k} and DksubscriptDğ‘˜\\mathrm{D}\_{k} determine the transmission direction of ğ…kEsubscriptsuperscriptğ…ğ¸ğ‘˜{\\mathbf{F}}^{E}\_{k} for each iteration, the studentsâ€™ network for random block information is also exchanged and transmitted by the teacherâ€™s as Fig. [2]Figure 2 â€£ 3 Methodology â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") shown.

where Î»râ€‹eâ€‹csubscriptğœ†ğ‘Ÿğ‘’ğ‘\\lambda\_{rec}, Î»kâ€‹dsubscriptğœ†ğ‘˜ğ‘‘\\lambda\_{kd}, Î»fâ€‹eâ€‹aâ€‹tsubscriptğœ†ğ‘“ğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘¡\\lambda\_{feat}, Î»bâ€‹lâ€‹oâ€‹câ€‹ksubscriptğœ†ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘˜\\lambda\_{block} represent the weights for reconstruction loss, logits-kd loss, feature prior mixer and block prior mixer respectively.

4 Experimental Results.content:
### 4.1 Experiment Setups

Backbones and Evaluation. We use EDSR \[ [21]\], RCAN \[ [49]\], and SwinIR \[ [20]\] as backbone models to verify the effectiveness of MiPKD and compare it with prior KD methods on Ã—2absent2\\times 2, Ã—3absent3\\times 3, and Ã—4absent4\\times 4 super-resolving scales.

We compare MiPKD with the baselines: train from scratch, Logits-KD \[ [12]\], RKD \[ [28]\], AT \[ [43]\], FitNet \[ [32]\], FAKD \[ [11]\], and CSD \[ [40]\]. Since the CSD is a self-distillation method in the channel-spliting manner, itâ€™s not applicable to the RCAN experiments of network depth distillation.
The results for Ã—4 EDSR trained with CSD are obtained by testing the provided checkpoint, and the Ã—2 and Ã—3 ones are reproduced by us since the checkpoints are unavailable.
To evaluate quality of SR modelâ€™s output, we calculate the peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) and the structural similarity index (SSIM) on the Y channel of the YCbCr color space. We use 800 images from DIV2K \[ [35]\] for training and evaluate SR models on four benchmark datasets: Set5 \[ [2]\], Set14 \[ [45]\], BSD100 \[ [25]\], and Urban100 \[ [14]\].

Training Details. All models are trained using Adam \[ [17]\] optimizer with Î²1=0.9subscriptğ›½10.9\\beta\_{1}=0.9, Î²2=0.99subscriptğ›½20.99\\beta\_{2}=0.99 and Ïµ=10âˆ’8italic-Ïµsuperscript108\\epsilon=10^{-8}, with a batch size of 16 and a total of 2.5Ã—1052.5superscript1052.5\\times 10^{5} updates. The initial learning rate is set to 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4} and is decayed by a factor of 10 at every 105superscript10510^{5} iteration. We set the loss weights Î»1subscriptğœ†1\\lambda\_{1} and Î»2subscriptğœ†2\\lambda\_{2} to 10 and 1, respectively. The proposed MiPKD is implemented by the BasicSR \[ [39]\] and PyTorch \[ [30]\] framework and train them using 4 NVIDIA V100 GPUs. The LR images used for training and evaluation were obtained by down-sampling the HR images with the bicubic degradation method. During training, the input images are randomly cropped into 48Ã—48484848\\times 48 patches and augmented with random horizontal/vertical flips and rotations.

Comparison with Baseline Methods.
Quantitative results for training EDSR \[ [21]\], RCAN \[ [49]\], and SwinIR \[ [20]\] of three SR scales
are presented in [Tab.2]In 4.1 Experiment Setups â€£ 4 Experimental Results â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution"), [Tab.3]In 4.1 Experiment Setups â€£ 4 Experimental Results â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") and [Tab.4]In 4.2 Results and Comparison â€£ 4 Experimental Results â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution"), from which we can draw the following conclusions:

(1) Existing KD methods for SR have limited effects, some may even deteriorate the student model. The KD methods originally designed for high-level CV tasks (RKD, AT, FitNet), though applicable, hardly improve the SR models over training from scratch. For instance, AT and FitNet underperform the vanilla student models trained without KD among all settings.

(2) The presented MiPKD outperforms existing KD methods baseline in width and depth compression, respectively.
For example, MiPKD outperforms the vanilla student in the most challenging dataset Urban100 in EDSRÃ—\\times2, Ã—\\times3, and Ã—\\times4 settings by
0.56 dB, 0.42 dB, 0.24 dB

0.2 dB, 0.17 dB, 0.19 dB
in terms of PSNR are improved, respectively, on Urban100 dataset in RCAN Ã—\\times2, Ã—\\times3, and Ã—\\times4 settings as [Tab.3]In 4.1 Experiment Setups â€£ 4 Experimental Results â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") shown.

(3) The MiPKD is applicable to Transformer network and able to boost the modelâ€™s performance. Conventional feature-based KD methods are not directly applicable to the Transformer-type networks, so we compare MiPKD with training from scratch and the response-based KD \[ [12]\] in the experiments. The results in  [Tab.4]In 4.2 Results and Comparison â€£ 4 Experimental Results â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") indicate that the MiPKD could improve the transformer SR model by a large margin, further emphasizing its superior performance.

Evaluate MiPKD on high compression rate setting. [Tab.5]In 4.2 Results and Comparison â€£ 4 Experimental Results â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") shows the results of training Ã—4 scale EDSR model compressed in both network width and depth dimensions. The number of parameters are compressed for about 28 times from teacher model.
Directly distilling the student model by the teacher model yields negative effects on its performance. Two-stage KD with an intermediate teaching-assistant (TA) model \[ [26]\] are necessary in such case.
To make use of the CSD method, we compared different TA options, (1) Teacher->Student1->Student2: the whole pipeline is in a width-then-depth compression order. We adopt CSD to train the TA and FAKD for student. model (2) Depth-then-width: we first perform depth compression and then width compression. We adopt FAKD+CSD and MiPKD+MiPKD for the two-stage distillations. Using MiPKD to train both TA and student model yields the best results.

For instance, for iâ€‹mâ€‹gâ€‹\_â€‹047ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘”\_047img\\\_047, MiPKD can reconstruct much better fine details than all baseline work. FAKD are prone to artifacts in the left-bottom of the building and the vanilla student, Logits-KD, FAKD, and FitNet are over-blurred. In contrast, MiPKD alleviates the blurring artifacts and reconstructs much more structural details. Similar observations can be found in other cases, e.g. the characters and anisotropic textures in iâ€‹mâ€‹gâ€‹\_â€‹073ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘”\_073img\\\_073. These visual comparisons are consistent with the quantitative results, demonstrating the superiority of MiPKD. More visual comparisons can be found in the supplementary materials.

5 Ablation Study.content:
To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed MiPKD scheme, we conduct detailed ablation studies on Ã—multiple scale RCAN and EDSR networks.

Ablation on the feature and block prior mixers for MipKD.
There are two fine-grained prior mixer modules in MiPKD, namely, the feature and block prior mixers. Their individual effects are ablated in [Tab.6]In 5 Ablation Study â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution"). The result shows that employing the feature prior mixers leads to significant performance improvement and the block prior mixer based on it could further boost the student model.

Ablation on the MiPKD feature prior mixer module.
In the feature prior mixer module of MiPKD, the teacher and student modelsâ€™ feature maps are mapped to the latent space through corresponding encoders, thereby randomly mixed and stitched.
We present an analysis of the impact of the encoders in [Tab.7]In 5 Ablation Study â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") by comparing MiPKD with 1) removing the encoders, aligning and utilizing the teacherâ€™s feature map directly and 2) sharing a encoder among the teacher and student model.
Removing the encoders would substantially deteriorate the student modelâ€™s performance. Due to the different distribution of teacher and student modelsâ€™ feature maps, a shared encoder cannot effectively map them to the same latent space, leading to noisy mixtures.
Assigning the teacher and student models separate encoders yields the best results, indicating that mixing feature priors in the same latent space is necessary.

[Tab.8]In 5 Ablation Study â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution") compares the encoders and decoder of different architecture. The result shows that convolutional neural network type exhibits better performance and is more suitable in SR task.

Besides, the strategies of the mask generation are compared in [Tab.9]In 5 Ablation Study â€£ Knowledge Distillation with Multi-granularity Mixture of Priors for Image Super-Resolution"). Compared with 1) masking according to the Cosine or CKA similarity between teacher and student modelsâ€™ feature maps or 2) generating the complementary pairs of feature map by fixed grid pattern, the random 3D-mask exhibits the best performance and least calculation consumption. A more flexible, generalisable strategy is applied in the prior mixer module.

6 Conclusion.content:
In this paper, we present MiPKD, a simple yet significant KD framework for SR with feature and block mixers.
By incorporating the prior knowledge from teacher model to the student, the capacity disparity between them are reduced, and the feature alignment is achieved effectively.
We compare the proposed MiPKD with various kinds of distillation methods and demonstrate the superiority of our solutions.
For instance, it improves the EDSR network of three SR scale on Urban100 testing set in the range of 0.24 dBâˆ¼similar-to\\sim0.56 dB in terms of PSNR.
The presented MiPKD outperforms existing KD methods baseline in width, depth compression and compounded compression in SR tasks, which is flexible to a wide array of teacher-student kd architectures.
